qas.question: What religions did Tugh Temur reject?

context: Due to the fact that the bureaucracy was dominated by El Temür, Tugh Temür is known for <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>his <b5_0>cultural contribution<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> instead. He adopted many measures honoring Confucianism and promoting Chinese cultural values. His most concrete effort to patronize Chinese learning was founding the <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>Academy of the Pavilion of the Star of Literature<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> (Chinese: 奎章閣學士院), first established in <a2_2>the <a2_0><b7_0>spring of <a2_1>1329<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> and designed to undertake "a number of tasks relating to the transmission of Confucian high culture to the Mongolian imperial establishment". The academy was responsible for compiling and publishing a number of books, but its most important achievement was its compilation of a vast institutional compendium named <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>Jingshi Dadian<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> (Chinese: 經世大典). Tugh Temür <a4_0><b9_0>supported Zhu Xi's <a4_2>Neo-Confucianism and also devoted himself in <a4_1>Buddhism<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>.
